Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, my phone buzzing in my hand. My younger brother’s message glowed on the screen: “Can we talk? I really need you.” He never asked for help unless it was serious. As his sister, I’d always promised to be there, to listen, to support him no matter what. But just as I was about to call him, another message popped up—this time from a community member. “Salam, Imam. If you have a moment today, I’d love to get your advice about something important.” I knew how much people relied on me for guidance, how they trusted me to be available, to offer comfort and wisdom. My heart twisted. I wanted to be the sister my brother needed, but I also felt the weight of my responsibility as imam. Both roles demanded my presence, my empathy, my time—right now. I stared at the two messages, feeling the pressure build inside me, torn between the family I loved and the community that depended on me.
